;;B;;ELLY DOWN; 在泥泞的荷兰森林中，萨布丽娜·范·登·古尔伯格 (Sabrina van den Goorbergh) 从柯尔特<小>;C7;突击步枪。这位三年级医学生正在参加“Dienjaar”（服役年），这是一项新计划，允许年轻的荷兰人报名参加武装部队为期一年的试用，而不是常规的四年制服役。年入伍期限。该计划取得了成功，每个名额吸引了三名申请者，政府计划明年将培训人数从 625 名增加到 1,000 名。

;;
;;< /div>;

;然而，它还很难开始解决该国的招聘问题。荷兰武装部队人数为 49,000 人，不到冷战时期的五分之一，而且十分之一的职位空缺。去年，常规入伍的新兵人数仅为 3,600 人，而原本希望的 5,000 名新兵却只有 3,600 人。此时此刻，面对欧洲大陆自1945年以来最大规模的战争，许多欧洲国家实际上希望扩大武装力量，而不仅仅是维持武装力量。到2030年，德国希望将其驻军人数从182,000人增加到203,000人，法国则从240,000人增加到275,000人（见图1）。波兰计划到今年年底将数量从 197,000 增加到 220,000，最终达到 300,000。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;问题在于，如今以事业为导向、个人主义的年轻人不愿意加入。陷入招聘困境的不仅仅是欧洲。在世界冲突热点地区及其周边地区，如何让更多的人穿上军装至关重要。一些国家正在重新考虑一个旧的解决方案：对年轻人（或年轻人）（通常是高中毕业生）强制服兵役。术语各不相同。征兵通常意味着强迫平民加入武装部队，而兵役通常指其中的一个子集——命令年轻人在部队服役。

;

;20世纪初，大约80%的国家实行某种形式的征兵制；到 2010 年代中期，这一比例略低于 40%。这种做法在世界大战期间达到顶峰，许多国家在整个冷战期间继续依赖它。此后，西方的焦点转向高科技平叛活动，例如在阿富汗和伊拉克的活动。大规模应征入伍的军队大多被规模较小的专业志愿军所取代。自 1995 年以来，<小>;经合组织;（一个主要由富裕国家组成的俱乐部）的 13 个成员国已经取消了征兵制度。 ;北约; 32 个成员国中，除了 8 个成员国外，其余所有成员国都废除了这一制度。但伊朗、朝鲜和俄罗斯等专制国家已加倍加强其强征军队。

;

;围绕强制军事的最紧迫的讨论服役和征兵是在面临严重战争威胁或已经面临战争威胁的国家进行的。以乌克兰为例。俄罗斯入侵两年多后，数千名男子逃离该国边境，或躲藏起来，以避免收到入伍文件。 4 月 2 日，由于缺乏军队，乌克兰政府被迫将最低入伍年龄从 27 岁降低到 25 岁。俄罗斯已将数十万强行动员的士兵投入战争的绞肉机中。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;在以色列，军事职责是公民身份的核心支柱。 10 月 7 日的袭击事件发生后，约 30 万以色列人脱离平民生活，匆忙加入他们的部队。以色列希望将男性应征入伍者的服役期限延长至三年（目前年轻女性服役期为 24 个月，年轻男性为 32 个月），并将预备役军人的征召年龄延长至 45 岁。服务是一场激烈的政治斗争的主题。

;

;与此同时，在亚洲，台湾正在努力为可能与中国发生的战争做准备，因为中国-美国的紧张局势持续存在。台湾于2022年将兵役期从四个月延长至一年。但该岛仍拥有 169,000 名现役士兵（中国约有 200 万）。韩国的兵役制度素有野蛮的名声，但韩国正在努力让其更具吸引力。服役期缩短至 18 个月，工资上涨，虐待狂的教官也被裁减。政府还希望雇用更多女性（仅限男性征兵加剧了男性的不满和反女权主义政治）。

;
;;
;

;在许多地方，武装部队的征兵人员在价值观转变面前举步维艰：年轻人越来越厌恶甚至在防御战中也能战斗。几十年来，学术研究项目世界价值观调查（;WVS;）一直在向世界各地的人们提出同样的问题：“你愿意为你的国家而战吗？”在 2017 年至 2022 年间的最新一轮调查中，只有 36% 的 16 至 29 岁荷兰人表示愿意（见图 2）。

;

;招聘人员试图用爱国主义、自我实现和共同价值观的言辞进行反击；德国武装部队联邦国防军的口号是“Wir”。迪南。德国。;（我们服务德国。）他们还在 TikTok 和 Instagram 上与有影响力的人一起开展活动。但这似乎还不足以达到他们的目标。

;

;这在一定程度上是意料之中的。随着国家变得更加富裕，其公民往往不再那么渴望为国家牺牲自己。德国政治学家赫尔弗里德·明克勒（Herfried Münkler）将西方民主称为“后英雄”社会，其中“最高价值是保护人类生命”和个人福祉。历史确实发挥了作用。第二次世界大战战败国（德国、意大利和日本）的战斗意愿较低。在西班牙和葡萄牙，数十年的军事独裁让许多公民对武装部队产生了怀疑。

;

;但当冲突临近时，情况可能会发生变化。阿姆斯特丹自由大学的 Wolfgang Wagner 和 Alexander Sorg 以及鹿特丹伊拉斯姆斯大学的 Michal Onderco 即将发表的论文指出，临近战争使公民更愿意参战。在欧洲，这有助于解释为什么靠近俄罗斯的国家不那么鸽派。

;
;;
;

;政治联盟并不能很好地预测人们是否愿意携带武器。瓦格纳表示，“激进右翼并不那么渴望战斗”，至少在德国和荷兰是这样。去年，他和他的同事委托在这些国家进行了一项研究，结果发现，计划投票给极左或极右政党的人很少愿意为自己的国家而战。那些支持德国社会民主党和基督教民主党等中间派政党的人更愿意这样做。

;

;除了价值观的改变之外，征兵人员还年轻人面临经济障碍：目前有很多雇主竞标他们的服务。在大多数富裕国家，Z 一代都有自己的工作选择。去年，欧盟 15 至 24 岁人群的失业率为 14.5%，低于 2015 年的 22.4%。德国仅为 5.8%。在劳动力市场如此紧张的情况下，军队很难与私营部门竞争。此外，坐在办公桌前比在泥巴里爬行要好得多。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;然而，在一些富裕国家，年轻人的战斗意愿仍然很高。在法国，;WVS; 的份额为 58%。新加坡、台湾和韩国的这一数字更高。在丹麦、芬兰、挪威和瑞典这四个世界上最富有、最和平的国家，三分之二或更多的公民表示他们愿意。 （都靠近俄罗斯。）他们不断扩张的武装部队在寻找士兵方面也不存在困难：所有四个国家都对年轻人实行义务兵役制。

;

;瑞典实际上在 2011 年就取消了这种做法，但在未能实现招聘目标后于 2018 年恢复了这种做法。对于其他人来说，这是一个有趣的案例研究。刚加入;北约;后，它的士兵人数从 69,700 人增加到 96,300 人，每年需要招募约 10,000 名新兵。全国所有19岁的人（男性和女性）都必须填写服务调查问卷；略低于三分之一的人符合资格，十分之一的人最终入伍。

;

;在瑞典，义务兵役并没有让年轻人对武装部队感到厌烦。似乎让他们更加热情。国防部长帕尔·琼森 (Pal Jonson) 表示，在服役结束时的退出调查中，“大约 80% 的应征入伍者会推荐其他年轻人服兵役”。大约 30% 的人重新入伍，成为士兵或预备役人员。由于符合资格的年轻人数量超出了需要，因此只有最优秀的候选人才能加入，并且服兵役在一个人的;简历;上看起来很不错。

;

;这种征兵有助于使北欧军队成为不同阶级的熔炉，并阻止政治两极分化。 （武装部队中的志愿者往往倾向于右倾；在德国，联邦国防军中已经发现了新纳粹组织。）在中东也是如此，许多国家将年轻人服兵役视为社会粘合剂。阿拉伯联合酋长国于 2014 年推出这一举措，部分原因是为了在年轻人中建立一种共同的认同感。摩洛哥、约旦和科威特也纷纷效仿。

;;

;

;许多民主国家的不足表明更好的招募策略对增加部队数量的作用有限。很少有医学生像范登古尔伯格女士那样愿意同时接受步兵训练。在自由社会中，很大一部分人已经将参军视为别人的工作。重新对年轻人实行义务兵役制可能在政治上和实践上都不可行，原因与招募不足的原因相同：公民感到与武装部队疏远。

;

;然而，北欧模式似乎有助于弥合这一差距，确保服兵役仍然是社会生活的自然组成部分，并促使更多的毕业生考虑相关职业。其他年轻人可能仍然只有在危机时才会参军。 “正是恐惧促使你采取行动，”前电视制片人、目前在乌克兰东部作战的安德烈说。他在俄罗斯入侵后的第二天就报名了。大多数乌克兰人也不相信他们需要为自己的国家而战。 ;■;

As the former ;MEP ;addressed several hundred fellow-travellers of the hard right at a conference, Belgian police swooped into the venue with orders to shut the event down.由于寡不敌众，警察们最终谨慎地撤退，这让法拉奇先生能够对那些贪图公道的欧洲官员和假新闻媒体发表更多的俏皮话。 After some to and fro, the police opted to seal the conference venue instead, leaving the afternoon's speakers stuck outside and—worse, for attendees including Charlemagne—caterers unable to deliver food. Not to worry: lunch was replaced by a stern lecture from Suella Braverman, Britain's former home secretary, about the dastardliness of human-rights lawyers.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The half-hearted police raid at a reactionary gabfest was the culmination of a discomfiting series of events around the “National Conservatism” conference on April 16th-17th. At the ninth such jamboree, organised by the Edmund Burke Foundation, an American outfit, the star attraction of this iteration was Viktor Orban, Hungary's proudly illiberal prime minister.毫不奇怪，一些发言者的观点超出了中间派共识，尽管这些观点得到了很多选民的认可。 This ;lèse-libéralisme; sent local Belgian authorities on a misguided mission to prove the “cancel culture” decried by conservatives is not just a conspiracy. A policy that aims to exclude hard-right parties from coalition governments, known as the ;cordon sanitaire;, metastasised into an ugly variant whereby merely expressing such ideas is beyond the pale.

;

;The first sign of trouble came a few days before the event, when its original venue, a posh set of heavily gilded rooms near the ;EU; institutions used by political parties and diplomats for their own shindigs, decided to turf out the conservatives. One of Brussels's 19 district mayors had ginned up fears of “anti-fascist” protests, arguing that security was impossible to arrange.这显然是无稽之谈。布鲁塞尔举办了数十场峰会，其中的达官贵人却没有遇到此类问题。当国家保守党集团于 2022 年在同一地点举办类似活动时，治安也不是问题。尽管审查制度的表现令人不安，但还会有更多的审查。布鲁塞尔的备用场地位于欧洲议会附近的索菲特大酒店，这里也经常举办政治会议。 As the conservative organisers were in the midst of setting up their stage on the day before the event, another Brussels district mayor worked to evict them, taking pride in foiling the conference of people whose views he disagrees with.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;And thus it was that the homeless nationalists ended up cramped inside the Claridge, a former nightclub turned into a concert venue and part-time conference hall (with no connection to the luxurious London hotel, nor anything remotely posh). If the site originally booked was the Ritz of political rallies, this was more akin to a roadside motel, jammed between a second-hand clothes shop and a kebab joint in Belgium's poorest district;即将举行的活动包括以怪物史莱克为主题的狂欢（“带出你内心的食人魔！”）。 Even then, yet another Brussels mayor sent in the cops.

;

;The offstage rigmarole spiced up what was otherwise predictable globalist-bashing fare.那些能够参加的演讲者——法国煽动者埃里克·泽穆尔（Eric Zemmour）就是其中之一，尽管第一天就被警方禁止——发表了有关家庭价值观和偏执的精英的陈词滥调。 Among the forces to be combated: the European Parliament, the European Commission, the mainstream media, polite society, the ;UN;, immigrants, political correctness, ;NGO;s, “Bolshewokism”, George Soros, and green regulation.会议发言人喜欢的东西包括热爱自由的克拉里奇酒店业主、农民、唐纳德·特朗普、国家主权、母性和“人民的意志”。 Conspicuously absent, as well as lunch (which did arrive later, for there is only so much self-sacrifice even conservatives will put up with), was any kind of speech a liberal society should not be able to tolerate.

;Conservatives at the gates

;

;Charlemagne holds little truck with the ideas featured at the conference.许多善意的演讲者，尤其是来自美国的演讲者，似乎没有意识到他们的匈牙利赞助人（他们为这次活动提供了资金）滥用了他们的保守意识形态，并以此为掩护，建立了一个有利于裙带内部人士的赞助制度。有些人，比如泽穆尔先生，持有真正应受谴责的观点。但被误导是他们的事，而不是思想警察或布鲁塞尔变体的事。令人高兴的是，事实证明，这种笨手笨脚的审查制度是可以克服的。会议第一天结束时，比利时首相亚历山大·德克罗谴责关闭会议的企图“不可接受”。法院连夜做出裁决，撤销了最初禁止该活动的命令。 Boosted by the furore around the efforts of his liberal enemies to silence him, Mr Orban got to address his fans, railing against the ;EU ;and the very liberal norms that (belatedly) ensured his right to speak;.;

;

;Stuck between the hubbub of police blockading the venue and persecuted conservatives within, your columnist got to chat for a few minutes with the owner of the Claridge.拉萨德·本·亚赫兰 (Lassaad Ben Yaghlane) 是来自突尼斯的第一代移民，他与家人一起经营这个地方已有十年。当他接到主办这次活动的电话时，他在同意之前想了想，然后决定为任何人提供辩论的空间不会有什么坏处。他说，保守派组织者都是很有礼貌的人。 Didn't he mind that some speakers were spewing migrant-bashing rhetoric from a stage he was providing? The 59-year-old shrugged and asked: “What's a democracy if you say, 'You can listen to this guy but not that one'?”;■;

;;“B;;uildings of England”;, the Bible of architectural historians, is effusive about the Grand Hotel in Scarborough, a chilly, rather tired seaside resort on the coast of Yorkshire. It is “a High Victorian gesture of assertion and confidence: of denial of frivolity and insistence on substance, than which none more telling can be found in the land”.

;

;Other reviews vary. “绝对可怕，”其中写道。 “如果我能给它0，我会的！”另一位说。第三个人生动地回忆道：“我住的第一个房间，床单上都是阴毛。”当白芝浩来访时，他避免了这种命运。但他发现，《英格兰建筑》中突出显示的“辉煌大厅”现在设有一张空气曲棍球桌和一台发光的街机，赌客可以在那里赢得 Xbox 控制器或一瓶 Prime（一种令人作呕的能量饮料）等奖品。 In the bar four bored pensioners watched “The Chase”, a quiz show, at a disconcertingly loud volume.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The Grand Hotel's owner is Britannia, which is consistently ranked the country's worst hotel chain. Soon it could have a new one: British taxpayers. Keane Duncan, the 29-year-old Conservative candidate for the newly formed York and North Yorkshire Combined Mayoral Authority, has pledged to buy the decaying hotel if he wins office in local elections on May 2nd. If Britannia refuses to sell, then Mr Duncan says he will use compulsory-purchase powers bestowed on the mayor to force them to do so. “Sounds bonkers, I know,” says Mr Duncan.

;

;When it comes to devolution in England, there is a broad consensus.保守党为在每个主要城市地区以及现在在一些农村地区引入地区市长而感到自豪。在未来的工党政府领导下，市长的权力将进一步增强。专家们普遍认为权力下放是“一件好事”。人们忘记的是，这也是一件非常混乱的事情。有些想法会起作用。其他人会失败。有些人会发疯。 Local politics is always a mixture of the good, the bad and the mad.

;

;For a taste of all three, drive 70 minutes north up the ;A;171 to Teesside, a struggling industrial region. Ben Houchen, the Conservative mayor of this traditionally Labour region, is fighting for re-election. His offer to voters is one of unapologetic economic interventionism. Almost £560m ($700m) of public money has been pledged to overhaul a 1,800-hectare site by the Tees in an effort to turn the graveyard of a former steelworks into something productive. Lord Houchen even bought a loss-making airport on the basis that executives could fly in to invest while Teessiders could fly out to spend the proceeds on the Med. “Dirigisme” is the idea that the state can orchestrate an economy; “Houchisme” is a shrunken version, with a local economy bossed by a regional big man.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The scheme has been dogged by accusations of mismanagement and worse. Andy McDonald, a local ;MP;, made allegations of “industrial-scale corruption” while speaking in Parliament, which is exempt from England's libel laws. Lord Houchen in turn labelled Mr McDonald a “liar”, a “coward” and a “disgrace”. A report has found no evidence of corruption but a litany of governance failures, with 28 changes recommended for the complex set-up.

;

;The project has, at times, taken a unique approach to stakeholder management. During one disagreement about access rights to the site with a neighbouring business, the then vice-chair of the development corporation opted for film-dialogue threats: “I want your eyes out of your head; I want the fucking roof off your house; I want your kids out of private school; I want no shoes on your fucking feet.” Devolution succeeds in putting the spotlight on sometimes forgotten areas; the glare will not always flatter.

;

;Sometimes devolved schemes are wacky but largely harmless.在英格兰西部联合管理局，市长推出了生日巴士通行证，让人们在生日当月免费乘车（花费 800 万英镑）。其他地方决策会产生更大的影响。 In Greater Manchester Andy Burnham, the Labour mayor, has attracted plaudits for bringing the region's bus system into public ownership but chickened out of a “clean-air zone” that would have charged polluting vehicles for driving in the centre of the region.萨迪克·汗在伦敦扩大了类似的计划，但付出了一定的政治代价。首都污染大幅下降； pollution in Manchester is the country's worst. If Manchester's residents choke, at least it is due to their own choices.

;

;This is part of the point of devolution. The British government and in particular its mighty Treasury is good at stopping sins of commission. White elephants do exist but they are rare, since so many projects are aborted moments after conception. As a result, however, sins of omission are common. Devolution means more things will be tried because of decisions made by local politicians. But that will, inevitably, lead to mistakes.

;;

;Having a right mayor

;

;At the moment, a place like Scarborough is stuck in limbo. Central government has neither the guts to let it die nor the will to try to resuscitate it. A mayor will neither change the weather (it is still woolly-hat weather in spring) nor return the town to its Victorian pomp. But someone might end up cleaning the layer of grime and seagull droppings that covered the window in Bagehot's filthy hotel room. Whether that is a good use of taxpayer money is for voters—or at least the fraction of them who bother to vote in local elections—to decide.

;

;Devolution is a long-term punt that local politicians will, on the whole, make better decisions about their area than national ones. Boosters insist a virtuous circle will kick in: more powers will attract higher-calibre candidates, which will lead to more scrutiny, which will mean better policy. Everyone in British politics has signed up to the gamble. The price in the short term? Whatever a 413-room Victorian hotel in Scarborough goes for these days. ;■;

;Traders had expected an attack of precisely this variety: big enough to cause concern;明显到足以被挫败。他们现在押注以色列将避免做出过于鲁莽的回应。然而，即使油价没有飙升，价格仍然处于令人不安的高位，并且在夏季似乎还会进一步上涨，届时供应紧张而需求增加可能会使市场陷入短缺。 A cast of decision-makers—from central bankers to President Joe Biden, who faces re-election in November—is watching anxiously.

;

;Geopolitical risk explains, in part, why oil prices have risen by a quarter since December. 4 月 1 日以色列轰炸伊朗驻大马士革领事馆后，布伦特原油价格近六个月来首次突破 90 美元。供应中断正在发挥更大的作用。墨西哥正在削减出货量，以便在国内生产更多汽油。一条漏水的苏格兰管道被迫关闭。利比亚的动荡正在扰乱产出； war in South Sudan could do the same.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Meanwhile, tougher sanctions on Russia are leaving more of its oil stranded. 3 月份，印度炼油厂（2022 年以来俄罗斯第二大买家）表示，由于担心西方报复，他们将不再欢迎俄罗斯国有航运公司 Sovcomflot 拥有的油轮。 Most of the 40-odd tankers sanctioned by America since October have not loaded Russian oil since. The ;reimposition of sanctions; on Venezuela could further dent supply. America may also decide to better police its existing embargo on Iran's oil sales.

;

;The biggest supply disruption is deliberate. It is coming from the ;Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies; (;OPEC;+). 11月，该组织承诺将产量削减220万桶/日，即全球产量的2%。大多数观察家曾预计，由于 2024 年价格可能会上涨，成员国将趁机抵制降价。相反，一些公司在三月份宣布将把期限延长至六月底。 Russia even said it would deepen its cuts by another 471,000 b/d, reducing output to 9m b/d, from 10.8mb/d pre-war.

;
;;
;

;Last year supply growth outside the cartel more than made up for the rise in要求。 This year non-;OPEC; output will rise again—Brazil and Guyana are expected to pump record amounts—but growth will slow.全球石油库存已经在下降； they will shrink faster this summer, as holidaymakers in America take to the road.

;

;All this is happening in the face of robust demand.美国、中国和欧洲的制造业活动指标出人意料地上升，导致官方预测机构国际能源署预测，今年全球原油需求将平均增加 1.2 兆瓦/日，高于 90 万桶/日。 /d 十月份建议的。 Others, including some big traders and ;OPEC ;itself, reckon demand growth may near or surpass 2m b/d.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Where will the oil price go next? If ;OPEC;+ keeps its cuts unchanged, it could reach $100 within months.但这并不是卡特尔真正想要的结果。许多成员国，尤其是沙特阿拉伯，担心油价快速上涨可能会破坏需求。原油价格上涨正在推动美国汽油价格从每加仑 3.60 美元逼近 4 美元。摩根大通银行估计，如果油价飙升超过这一点，夏季汽油需求可能会减少 20 万桶/日。 Thus ;OPEC;+ may signal its intention to produce more at its next meeting. Jorge León, a former ;OPEC ;analyst now at Rystad Energy, a consultancy, expects crude to average $90 a barrel in the third quarter of the year and $89 in the final quarter. Futures markets are even more sanguine: buying crude for delivery in December costs around $85 a barrel.

;;

;Black cloud

;

;Even if the tit-for-tat between Israel and Iran escalates, it is unlikely to change much. Any reduction in Iran's exports—worth 1.6mb/d in March—might be balanced by more pumping from the rest of ;OPEC;.在最坏的情况下，伊朗可能决定关闭霍尔木兹海峡，这是一条连接海湾和印度洋的水道，世界上 30% 的海上石油以及几乎所有海湾石油都必须经过该海峡。这样做会激怒该地区的几乎所有人，并切断伊朗与其唯一石油买家：中国的联系。也许伊朗会选择以较少自残的方式制造麻烦，例如骚扰海湾的船只。 Yet even the Tanker War of the 1980s—when hundreds of tankers were attacked—failed to durably boost prices.

;

;The most likely scenario, therefore, is that oil prices remain tolerable to the world economy, at somewhere in the region of $85-90 a barrel, while allowing ;OPEC ;members to earn juicy margins.不过，价格不太可能很快下跌。而这样的水平对于美国选民来说是否能够忍受则完全是另一回事了，因为他们每天都会看到高速公路上以大红色数字广告的汽油价格。 ;■;

;;A;;远为;按照刻板印象，傲慢的民族自信长期以来一直是美国人在国外被视为的一个决定性特征。 2006 年，当盖洛普首次开始询问美国人对关键机构的信任度时，该国在 G7 排行榜上名列前茅，与英国并列。 2023 年，美国首次垫底。

;;
;;
;

;盖洛普的新数据显示，美国人对多个国家机构的信任度正在下降。考虑到该国令人担忧的政治状况，这可能并不令人惊讶，但多年来的累计下降令人震惊（见图表）。二十年前，在任何<小>;七国集团国家中，美国人对他们的人民政府拥有最高的信心。今天他们的成绩是最低的。美国人与意大利人一样，对司法系统的信任度最低，对诚实选举的信心也垫底。就连军队也陷入了衰退。尽管美国对其武装部队的信任度仍高达 81%，但目前已低于 2006 年以来的任何时候，甚至低于法国。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;原因这场自称为地球上最伟大国家的信任危机背后的原因是多种多样的。对政府（健康的）怀疑论的根源可以追溯到越南战争和 20 世纪 70 年代初的水门事件。最伟大一代的逐渐消亡也起到了一定作用，因为他们的机构信任度明显高于后代。然而，最近的事态发展有助于解释过去几年的急剧下降。

;

;唐纳德·特朗普对 2020 年总统的毫无根据的指控“不断炮轰”选举显然在美国人对;;罗伊诉韦德案;;。在这项裁决取消美国宪法规定的堕胎权之前，民主党人和共和党人对法院的信任程度大致相同。此后，民主党人的信心一落千丈。

;

;与英国的分歧尤其引人注目。尽管英国对该国司法和选举制度的信心高于调查历史上的任何时候，但美国却朝着相反的方向发展。大约 70% 的英国人现在表示，他们对选举的诚实性有信心，而美国人的这一比例只有 44%。

;

;;我们的英国政治记者Matthew Holehouse建议工党将通过关注城市和集聚优势来参与升级;;

;“提升”英格兰东南部以外的英国小镇的命运本来是鲍里斯·约翰逊命运多舛的标志性政策行政。凯尔·斯塔默爵士承诺将在约翰逊先生陷入困境的地方取得成功。在过去的一个月里，已经出现了关于如何进行的信号;工党政府将完成这项任务。
;
;英国关于如何使贫困地区繁荣的辩论被描述为（也许是简化的） 城镇与城市的争论。城镇阵营倾向于强调恢复它们作为经济中心的地位，通常是通过政府干预重振制造业。这种方法强调了工业在当地自豪感和认同感方面的作用，并强调了政治反弹的风险 (;例如英国脱欧;）当这些地方感觉被忽视时。它反映了这样一种观念，即政策制定者的工作是确保人们不必为了获得高薪工作而离开出生地。
;
;相比之下，城市阵营认为小城镇的表现往往取决于最近城市的表现。它的倡导者强调集聚的经济效益，即大型活动集群往往会提高生产率；他们认为，改善小城镇命运的最佳途径是通过更好的交通基础设施将其劳动力市场与邻国的劳动力市场更好地连接起来。它反映了这样一个逻辑：让人们离工作更近比将工作重新安置给人们要容易得多。
;
;这些不是二元选择。事实上，保守党政府已经尝试两者兼而有之。它支持大城市地区市长的作用，例如大曼彻斯特的安迪·伯纳姆和;西米德兰兹郡的安迪街;。但它也通过“城镇基金”向较小的地方发放现金，通常用于改造当地购物商场等项目。但也有一些权衡：钱只能花一次。最明显的是，;Rishi Sunak 削减了;HS;2; 是一个大型城际铁路项目，并将资金转向道路维护等转型性较小的项目。保守党经常陶醉于文化怨恨政治，将城镇居民描绘成“真正的选民”，将城市居民描绘成享有特权的大都市。
;
;过去一个月已经清楚的是，在工党政府的领导下，这座城市以主导的方式将占据主导地位。这并非已成定局。这种城镇化的做法得到了丽莎·南迪(Lisa Nandy)的支持，她直到最近还是工党的影子地方政府秘书，也是威根的议员，威根是曼彻斯特和利物浦之间的一个前煤矿席位。她批评了一种“将城市视为经济增长引擎，而周边城镇最多只能依附于城市并跟随其繁荣发展”的做法。鉴于工党的政治战略一直侧重于较小的城镇，而不是已经在选举中占主导地位的城市，如果南迪女士的做法占上风，那就有意义了。
;
;然而，有明显迹象表明工党的辩论不走南迪女士的路。在贝叶斯商学院最近的一次重要演讲中，影子财政大臣雷切尔·里夫斯坚定地支持城市方案。她说：“随着我们经济的发展，我们需要采取更多措施来释放英国各地集聚的好处。”她引用了美国经济学家埃德·格莱泽 (Ed Glaeser) 的话，他是《城市的胜利》一书的作者，这是一篇关于致密化好处的关键文章。
;
;前进的方向在该党发表的一份政策文件中得到了确认3月28日。报告认为，英国主要城市的人口密度和联系不够紧密，无法实现繁荣，并建议迫使地区领导人制定跨越行政边界的增长计划。这篇论文充满了聚集的语言。以工党计划建造 150 万套新住房的这段非常具有启发性的段落为例：“这将增加我们主要城市和高潜力城镇的‘有效规模’，以便它们能够获得发展和巩固其城市所需的规模和集聚的好处。”劳动力市场集群和比较优势。”行话背后传达的信息很明确：越大越好。城市回来了。

;;I;;n 2019 a; federal judge named Alan Albright gave a presentation to a group of lawyers. His courthouse in Waco, Texas, where he is the only judge, sits near a sweet shop. The talk was called “Why You Should File Your Next Patent Case Across the Street from the 'Hey Sugar'”.

;

;The intellectual-property lawyers who heard his pitch were apparently persuaded. Less than two years after being appointed to the bench, he had nearly 20% of the country's patent cases, according to Lex Machina, a legal-analytics firm.到2021年，他的占有率达到23%。 Trial teams of white-shoe attorneys from New York and California, representing clients such as Google and Intel, began streaming into Waco, a city of 140,000 people in central Texas.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Bill Wetterman, a real-estate developer and Waco native, spotted a business opportunity. In 2021 he opened up Legal Lawfts, rentable office space—“war rooms”, in the parlance—that come outfitted with security cameras, back-up internet and, by request, gluten-free Oreos.

;

;In Waco Mr Wetterman's competitors include Connect Litigation, a firm that runs a few war rooms downtown. But Connect focuses its operations about 200 miles north-east. The “patent docket” is a familiar term in Marshall, a faded but quaint town of about 24,000 people near the Louisiana border. 2000 年至 2020 年间，联邦法院提交的所有专利案件中，超过 17% 发生在德克萨斯州东区，大约有 13,500 起。 By comparison Delaware, where most big American companies are incorporated, had fewer than 10,000 cases; the Northern District of California, where Big Tech firms are based, had fewer than 5,000.

;

;T. John Ward, Marshall's federal judge from 1999 to 2011, is responsible for the town's puzzling popularity. Patent cases are technical. Judges must referee the sharing of sensitive source code, for example: plaintiffs argue it will prove their case; defendants resist, fearing their secrets will leak. They also interpret what a patent's words actually mean, which can be “outcome determinative”, says Mark Siegmund, a patent litigator in Waco. Cases can also take years to get to trial.

;

;Mr Ward learned that Northern California's court had implemented local rules to build what lawyers call “certainty”—a predictable process—into the unwieldy cases. He adopted similar ones, tweaking them to prioritise speed. Litigants reached trial in half the time it took in California. Around the same period, “it also happened that there was an explosion of patent-troll litigation,” says Paul Gugliuzza of Temple University, referring to plaintiffs who own bad patents and seek quick and cheap settlements. By the mid-2010s Mr Ward's successor, Rodney Gilstrap, had about a quarter of the country's patent cases.

;;

;Patentsville, USA

;

;The caseload in Marshall books up the courthouse and boosts businesses downtown. One hotel bought a subscription to ;PACER;, an online database for court records, to keep track of potential clients. In an apparent bid to make locals (read: jurors) like it more, Samsung, a frequent defendant, sponsored an ice rink across from the courthouse. TiVo spent $10,000 on a champion steer at a livestock auction, and named it TiVo.

;

;This sits uneasily with some. Federal judges are meant to be generalists, and courts are not supposed to power their local economies. And the rules “tend to be more plaintiff-friendly”, says Andrew Russell, a patent litigator in Delaware. Defendants often try to transfer their cases elsewhere.但这在一定程度上是因为快速的节奏适合原告，因为财力雄厚的被告有能力拖延诉讼。 Early on, verdicts in the Eastern District were lopsided, because the posh defence lawyers were “terrible” at arguing before juries, says Michael Smith, a longtime patent litigator in Marshall. Verdicts in the Eastern District now conform to national averages.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;But the optics in Marshall were sufficiently bad that in 2017 the Supreme Court made it harder, in effect, for plaintiffs to file lawsuits there, by requiring defendants to have “regular and established” business where they are sued. Apple shut down its nearby stores. (Samsung did not and, despite the ice-rink, was hit with a $303m jury verdict in Marshall last year.)

;

;By 2021 Waco's patent docket—similarly speedy, thanks to local rules—was attracting scrutiny, too. John Roberts, the chief justice of the Supreme Court, acknowledged senators' concerns about the “extreme concentration of patent litigation” there. Starting in 2022 Waco patent cases were required to be put into a lottery, so that any of the Western District of Texas's 12 judges could draw them. In 2023 fewer patent cases were filed overall, and Waco saw a steep drop-off.

;

;Patent litigation could reasonably warrant a specialised court, similar to the system America uses to handle bankruptcy cases, stacked with experienced judges. “There are compelling reasons why Congress might think it was wise to create a national patent court,” says Steve Vladeck of the University of Texas. “The problem is that it's for Congress to decide, not the judge of the 37th-largest city in Texas.” Waco in fact ranks 24th in the state.马歇尔并列第138。;■;

;;G;;eneration Z is;接管。在富裕国家，至少有 2.5 亿人出生于 1997 年至 2012 年之间。其中大约一半人现在有工作。 In the average American ;workplace;, the number of Gen Zers (sometimes also known as “Zoomers”) working full-time is about to surpass the number of full-time baby-boomers, those born from 1945 to 1964, whose careers are winding down (see chart 1). Z 世代也在攫取权力：美国现在有 6,000 多名 Zoomer 首席执行官和 1,000 多名 Zoomer 政客。 As the generation becomes more influential, companies, governments and investors need to understand it.

;

;Pundits produce a lot of fluff about ;the cohort; 。薯片制造商菲多利 (Frito-Lay) 最近的“研究”发现，Z 世代非常喜欢“手指上留下残留物的零食”，例如奶酪粉。然而，不同代人的性格也表现出更深层次的差异，部分原因在于他们成长的经济背景。在 20 年代高通货膨胀时期成年的德国人开始厌恶物价上涨。 Americans who lived through the Depression tended to avoid investing in the stockmarket.

;;
;;
;

;Many argue that Gen Z is defined by its anxiety. Such worriers include Jonathan Haidt, a social psychologist at New York University, whose new book, “;The Anxious Generation;”, is making waves.从某些方面来说，Z 世代是不同寻常的。与过去相比，今天的年轻人不太可能建立人际关系。他们更有可能感到沮丧，或者说他们出生时被分配了错误的性别。他们不太可能喝酒、做爱、谈恋爱——事实上也不太可能做任何令人兴奋的事情。官方数据显示，15 岁至 24 岁之间的美国人平均每天仅花 38 分钟进行面对面社交，低于 2000 年代的近一个小时。 Mr Haidt lays the blame on smartphones, and the social media they enable.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;His book has provoked an enormous reaction. 4 月 10 日，阿肯色州州长萨拉·赫卡比·桑德斯 (Sarah Huckabee Sanders) 回应了海特的观点，概述了监管儿童使用智能手机和社交媒体的计划。英国政府正在考虑采取类似措施。但并非所有人都同意海特先生的论点。 Z 世代的焦虑情绪掩盖了该群体的另一种独特之处。从财务角度来看，Z 世代的表现非常出色。 This, in turn, is changing the generation's relationship with work.

;

;Consider the group that preceded Gen Z: millennials, who were born between 1981 and 1996. Many entered the workforce at a time when the world was reeling from the global financial crisis of 2007-09, during which young people suffered disproportionately. 2012-14 年，超过一半想要工作的西班牙年轻人找不到工作。希腊的青年失业率甚至更高。 Britney Spears's “Work Bitch”, a popular song released in 2013, had an uncompromising message for young millennials: if you want good things, you have to slog.

;

;Gen Zers who have left education face very different circumstances.发达国家的青年失业率约为 13%，自 1991 年以来从未如此低过（见图 2）。希腊的青年失业率已较峰值下降了一半。旅游胜地卡拉马塔的酒店经营者抱怨劳动力短缺，这在几年前是不可想象的。流行歌曲反映了时代精神。 2022 年，碧昂丝歌曲中的主角夸口说：“我刚刚辞去了工作”。 Olivia Rodrigo, a 21-year-old singer popular with American Gen Zers, complains that a former love interest's “career is really taking off”.

;
;;
;

;Many have chosen to study subjects that help them find work.在英国和美国，Z 世代正在回避人文学科，转而追求更明显有用的东西，比如经济和工程学。在没有上大学的人中，职业资格越来越受欢迎。然后他们继续从紧张的劳动力市场中受益。 Young people, following Beyoncé's protagonist, can quit their job and find another one if they want more money.

;

;In America hourly pay growth among 16- to 24-year-olds recently hit 13% year on year, compared with 6% for workers aged 25 to 54. This was the highest “young person premium” since reliable data began (see chart 3).在英国，年轻人的工资衡量方式不同，去年18岁至21岁的人平均每小时工资上涨了惊人的15%，大大超过了其他年龄段的工资涨幅。 In New Zealand the average hourly pay of people aged 20 to 24 increased by 10%, compared with an average of 6%.

;
;;
;

;Strong wage growth boosts family incomes.智库美国企业研究所的凯文·科林斯 (Kevin Corinth) 和美联储的杰夫·拉里莫尔 (Jeff Larrimore) 发表了一篇新论文，在考虑了税收、政府转移支付和通货膨胀后，按代评估了美国人的家庭收入（见图 4）。当千禧一代同龄时，他们的生活状况比 X 一代（1965 年至 1980 年出生的人）要好一些。然而，Zoom 一代的生活比同龄的千禧一代要好得多。 The average 25-year-old Gen Zer has an annual household income of over $40,000, more than 50% above the average baby-boomer at the same age.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Gen Z's economic power was on display at a recent concert by Ms Rodrigo in New York.出席的大部分是女性青少年和 20 多岁的人，他们花了数百美元买了一张票。 Queues for merchandise stalls, selling $50 ;t;-shirts, stretched around the arena.随着罗德里戈女士的巡演跨越大西洋，她在世界其他地区转移商品不会遇到任何困难。部分原因是，进入职场的 Z 世代在富裕国家赚了很多钱。 2007年，法国16岁至24岁人群的平均纯收入占总体平均水平的87%。现在等于92%。 In a few places, including Croatia and Slovenia, Gen Zers are now bringing in as much as the average.

;

;Some Gen Zers protest, claiming that higher incomes are a mirage since they do not account for the exploding cost of college and housing.毕竟，全球房价已接近历史高位，毕业生背负的债务也比以前更多。但事实上，Z 世代正在应对，因为他们的收入很高。 2022 年，25 岁​​以下的美国人将 43% 的税后收入用于住房和教育，包括大学债务利息——略低于 1989 年至 2019 年 25 岁以下人群的平均水平。他们的住房拥有率高于千禧一代。同龄。他们的税后收入储蓄也比 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代的年轻人更多。 They are, in other words, better off.

;
;;
;

;What does this wealth mean?千禧一代似乎从小就认为工作是一种特权，并采取了相应的行动。他们对老板毕恭毕敬，渴望取悦老板。相比之下，Zoomers 从小就相信工作基本上是一种权利，这意味着他们对工作有不同的态度。去年，Z 世代吹嘘“安静退出”，即他们付出了足够的努力才不被解雇。其他人则谈论“最低限度星期一”。寻求从专横的男性手中夺取企业控制权的“女老板”原型对千禧一代的女性很有吸引力。 Gen Z ones are more likely to discuss the idea of being “snail girls”, who take things slowly and prioritise self-care.

;

;The data support the memes. In 2022 Americans aged between 15 and 24 spent 25% less time on “working and work-related activities” than in 2007. A new paper published by the ;IMF ;analyses the number of hours that people say they would like to work.不久前，年轻人比老年人更愿意工作。现在他们想减少工作量。 According to analysis by Jean Twenge of San Diego State University, the share of American 12th-graders (aged 17 or 18) who see work as a “central part of life” has dropped sharply.

;

;Another consequence is that Gen Zers are less likely to be entrepreneurs. We estimate that just 1.1% of 20-somethings in the ;EU ;run a business that employs someone else—and in recent years the share has drifted down. In the late 2000s more than 1% of the world's billionaires, as measured by ;Forbes;, a magazine, were millennials.当时，专家们痴迷于超年轻的科技创始人，例如马克·扎克伯格（Facebook）、帕特里克·科里森（Stripe）和埃文·斯皮格尔（Snapchat）。 Today, by contrast, less than 0.5% on the ;Forbes ;list are Zoomers. Who can name a famous Gen Z startup founder?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Gen Zers are also producing fewer innovations.明尼苏达大学的拉塞尔·芬克 (Russell Funk) 表示，与最近相比，年轻人申请专利的可能性降低了。或者考虑一下 Billboard Hot 100，衡量美国最受欢迎的歌曲。 2008 年，42% 的热门歌曲是由千禧一代演唱的； 15 年后，只有 29% 的歌曲是由 Z 世代演唱的。世界上最受欢迎的歌手兼作曲家泰勒·斯威夫特 (Taylor Swift) 以她的出生年份命名了她最著名的专辑“1989”。 The world is still waiting for someone to produce “2004”.

;

;How long will Generation Z's economic advantage last?经济衰退对年轻人的打击比其他人更严重，经济衰退总是如此。人工智能可能会破坏全球经济的稳定，即使年轻人最终可能会更好地从这种破坏中受益。不过，就目前而言，Z 世代有很多值得高兴的事情。在麦迪逊广场花园的演出间隙，奥利维亚·罗德里戈坐在钢琴前，建议她的歌迷感谢他们所拥有的一切。 “成长真是太棒了，”她说。 “你有足够的时间去做你想做的所有事情。” The time ;and ;the money. ;■;

;;< p data-component="paragraph" class="css-1f0x4sl e1tt35bk0">;;F;;OR A SMALL; territory of 1.5m people, Chechnya has played a big role in shaping modern Russia. 20世纪90年代和2000年代初的车臣战争是苏联解体后发生的唯一一场发生在俄罗斯联邦境内的大型冲突。 They were also among the bloodiest: around 300,000 people died and the region's capital, Grozny, was obliterated.俄罗斯发动战争是为了防止分裂。 Vladimir Putin, Russia's president, lamented the “geopolitical disaster” of the Soviet breakup and warned in 2005 that Chechnya showed how Russia itself could catch the “epidemic of disintegration”.自2003年左右主要敌对行动结束以来，克里姆林宫一直将车臣作为镇压叛乱分子的典范。克里姆林宫首先任命前叛乱分子艾哈迈德·卡德罗夫为共和国领导人。 2007 年，他的儿子拉姆赞 (Ramzan) 继任。 The younger Mr Kadyrov has amassed vast wealth and built a private army known as the ;kadyrovtsy;.作为普京的忠实盟友，他已派遣数千名士兵援助乌克兰的俄罗斯入侵者。 (Pro-independence Chechens, meanwhile, have fought on Kyiv's side). These four books and one film show how Chechnya got here—and what this corner of the Caucasus says about Russia.

;;

;;Allah's Mountains: The Battle for Chechnya. ;By Sebastian Smith. ;Tauris Parke Paperbacks; 328 pages; £14.99.;

;

;In 1990 Boris Yeltsin, then Russia's leader, implored Russia's regions to “take as much sovereignty as you can吞”。车臣选举将支持独立的战斗机飞行员乔哈尔·杜达耶夫推上了权力宝座。与莫斯科的关系日益紧张，到 1994 年，冲突爆发。当时在车臣进行报道的塞巴斯蒂安·史密斯 (Sebastian Smith) 讲述了第一次战争以及自 1996 年以来不稳定的和平的故事。正如他所展示的，车臣人之所以能保持初出茅庐的状态，很大程度上要归功于他们的对手的无能和士气低落。一些俄罗斯士兵甚至将武器卖给车臣军队而不是战斗。但生存是有代价的。格罗兹尼陷落，又被夺回，并在此过程中被夷为平地。杜达耶夫在一次空袭中丧生。幸存下来的国家极其贫穷。 Organised crime and Islamic extremism flourished, then helped bring about a second war in 1999. Combining reportage with a broader history of the region's conflicts, this is the essential guide to the first war.

;

;;A Dirty War: A Russian Reporter in Chechnya. ;By Anna Politkovskaya. ;Harvill Press; 368 pages; £18.99.;

;

;The second Chechen war followed two calamities. One was the chaotic invasion in 1999 of neighbouring Dagestan by a Chechen warlord, Shamil Basayev. That attack enraged the Kremlin. The second was a series of deadly bombings of tower blocks in cities across Russia. The Kremlin blamed Chechen terrorists for the blasts and so had an excuse to try, once more, to subdue the region. ;Anna Politkovskaya; was a fiercely independent Russian journalist who produced scathing coverage of the Kremlin's corruption and rights滥用职权。 She described how the second campaign shifted from air strikes to the removal of Chechnya's government and, eventually, a counter-insurgency operation. Politkovskaya, who was murdered in Moscow in 2006, showed how Mr Putin used the war to focus public attention on himself. Her writing considers the ruined lives of ordinary Chechens, from elderly people abandoned in a care home to young men tortured during Russian “cleansing” missions. The book ends with a scene in a hospital which is characteristic of her powerful reporting: vivid descriptions and interviews with individual Chechens shift attention from high politics to the victims of war. Read our ;obituary of Anna Politkovskaya;.

;

;;From Conquest to Deportation: The North Caucasus under Russian Rule. ;By Jeronim Perovic. ;Hurst; 480 pages; £65.;

;

;Chechnya has a bloody history. Jeronim Perovic, a historian, traces the story of Russian rule in the North Caucasus, notably in Chechnya, beginning with Russian attempts in the 19th century to conquer the region and culminating in the Caucasian War. That decades-long campaign consumed, at one point, a sixth of the imperial budget. He explains how the Tsars and the Soviet Union recruited regional elites to crack down on local dissent. The climax of the book tells how Josef Stalin, fearing Chechens would collaborate with invading Germans in the second world war, banished over 600,000 people to Central Asia. The deported Chechens and other minorities were allowed back only in 1957. Among those displaced were Dudayev, then an infant, and the parents of Akhmad Kadyrov, who was born in exile in Kazakhstan. The memory of deportation remains painfully tangible for many Chechens. For the region's modern political exiles it is a lived reality.

;

;;The Cossacks and Other Stories. ;By Leo Tolstoy. ;Penguin; 528 pages; £10.99.;

;

;Leo Tolstoy has a claim to be one of Chechnya's favourite Russians. The writer spent the early 1850s as an artilleryman in the North Caucasus and lends his name to a village in Chechnya, Tolstoy-Yurt. Another settlement hosts a museum dedicated to his memory, funded partly by Ramzan Kadyrov, intended to foster Chechen affections for Russia. Tolstoy set two of his stories largely in Chechnya. “The Cossacks” he wrote early in his career; the other, “Hadji Murat”, he wrote at the end. The first opens with a description of a Cossack soldier who shamefully kills a young Chechen, sparking a cycle of violence that leads to a dreadful conclusion. The second is a portrait of a historical rebel who broke from Imam Shamil, a resistance leader, and forged an alliance with the Russians. Tolstoy's version of Hadji Murat's life depicts the divided loyalties and political intrigues driving those who fought over Chechnya in the Caucasian War. A thoughtful critique of imperial aggression, “Hadji Murat” gives a glimpse of the Caucasus seen through Russian eyes.

;

;;Welcome to Chechnya. ;Directed and produced by David France.

;

;Chechnya is a dark mirror of the Russian state. Mr Putin's regime is militaristic and ultra-conservative. So too is Mr Kadyrov's, though he makes distinctive appeals to Chechen tradition. Mr Kadyrov is especially ;hostile; to gay people, who face violent persecution and whose existence he denies. David France, an American filmmaker, posed as a tourist in order to make a film, “Welcome to Chechnya”, much of which he recorded on an iPhone. Following a network of activists who smuggle gay Chechens out of the republic, the documentary includes several escape attempts. Mr France's approach gives the film a claustrophobic feel, capturing something of the republic's repressive atmosphere. He uses deepfakes to disguise his vulnerable subjects' identities. The result is a reflection on repression and a tribute to activists who are determined to forge a better Chechnya. Read our full review of “; Welcome to Chechnya;”.

;; I;;T IS NO; accident that Israel and Iran are on the precipice of war. It is the result of long-standing agendas devised by misguided policymakers on both sides.
;
;Start with Iran.几十年来，其公开宣称的对以色列的仇恨和将这个国家从地图上抹去的决心一直是全力以赴的。 One struggles for a metaphor: Captain Ahab and the white whale?

;

;Iran's policy towards Israel has been geared towards two things it feels it needs to stand nose-to-nose with its adversary.首先是从以色列邻近地区发动攻击的能力。伊朗希望能够通过广泛的袭击来威胁以色列，从滋扰袭击到大规模地面和导弹袭击。因此，其在叙利亚和黎巴嫩的代理人非常重要。 The second perceived requirement is a nuclear-weapons system to match Israel's. Iran is yet to achieve that goal, and one can only guess at how its leaders would think about and wield the capability once it was acquired.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;George Washington believed that one country's extravagant hatred of another is sure to distort its foreign and domestic affairs in ways that get it into trouble. Iran exemplifies this point. Yet for the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic Republic, hostility to Israel validated both Iran's foreign policy and its domestic policy. The current crisis demonstrates vividly who has the better of the argument.
;
;Israel, for its part, has followed a strategic doctrine dubbed “the campaign between the wars”. The idea, driven by the recognition that major wars no longer produced decisive victories, was to maintain pressure on adversaries between such conflicts to deter them from starting one. The problem with this doctrine, long apparent outside Israel's security bubble, is now clear: it is virtually guaranteed to ignite such wars. As I have written before, one can never know whether the next bomb dropped will trigger a large-scale response. The Israelis have exploited Syrian airspace for years to attack Iran and its friends as they tried to construct a front against Israel in the Golan Heights and resupply Hizbullah's arsenal in Lebanon. In their campaign, the Israelis dropped that one bomb too many.
;
;These are not problems that America can solve. Its diplomatic intervention in a Middle East crisis works when regional adversaries value its help and America has a workable strategy. These conditions are, of course, reciprocal. America could work with Anwar Sadat and Menahem Begin, and with Yasser Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin. Forget about Binyamin Netanyahu and Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Israel's and Iran's current leaders. Their obstinacy is obvious. It needs stressing, nevertheless, given critics' claims that the current crisis reflects a failure of American strategy, or the suggestion that some clever formula emerging from the White House will bring peace.
;
;Iran has now selected the worst of all possible ploys in response to the twin pressures it was facing: to take a strong stand against Israel's campaign against Hamas in Gaza, and to respond to Israel's attack on the Iranian consulate in Syria. Iran had been handling the Gaza challenge well by limiting itself to political support for Palestinian militants and leaving kinetic resistance to Iranian proxies. But Iran's direct drone-and-missile attack on Israel has arguably turned Iran and its Palestinian partners into villains. Although it caused little damage and only one casualty, the unmistakable message was that such an attack, if larger and on shorter notice, could cause far greater destruction. It was ominous enough to call for a serious Israeli reply.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;For Israel's current government, pleas from America, the ;EU; and Gulf Arab states to refrain from responding in kind probably sound foolish. As Naftali Bennett, a former Israeli prime minister, has pointed out, the Iranians must have expected, and certainly desired, many deaths. Thus, he argues, the response should be scaled to what might have been rather than what actually was.

;

;If Israel does retaliate, as looks likely, it must decide not only how big to go but where: should the attack be aimed at Iran's proxies, targets within Iran or both? To complicate matters, Iran is shovelling large quantities of small arms into the West Bank to ignite the smouldering war there between Israeli settlers and Palestinian farmers. Having asserted that it would counter any Israeli response with a larger barrage and threatened to include American targets in any subsequent attacks, Iran is either prepared to risk war or foolishly assuming it is deterring it.

;

;Concerned states have done all they could to prevent escalation. Perhaps they will succeed. But the current state of politics in Israel and Iran and the poor quality of their respective leaderships counsel only the most cautious optimism. America has sharply increased its combat power in the region in the hope of giving Iran and its client militias pause, but it is now essentially hostage to Israel's response to Iran's latest provocation. The fact remains that American and Israeli interests would be best served if focus shifted from Iran's attack back onto resolving the crisis in Gaza. This would underscore Iran's irrelevance to the core issue and perhaps incentivise Israel to take the “day after” problem—the future of Gaza and broader Israeli-Palestinian relations—more seriously.

;

;The vexing question is how to engineer such a shift. The submerged anti-Iranian alliance broke the surface when Jordan, France and Britain joined Israel and America in countering Iran's attack. The ;EU; and the ;G;7 also condemned the Iranian attack. The ;EU; is especially irritated by Iran's informal alliance with Russia and its material support for Russia's war in Ukraine. To head off escalation, America and the ;EU; could propose a meeting of alliance members in lieu of an Israeli military response. Such a gathering—in, say, Riyadh, the Saudi Arabian capital—would be a powerful if non-kinetic rebuke to Iran. It might also encourage Israel to refocus on a swift conclusion of its campaign in Gaza, to agree on the deployment of a multinational peacekeeping force and to start co-operating with the new Palestinian prime minister, Mohammad Mustafa. Whether Mr Netanyahu and his radical cabinet would recognise the wisdom of a merely diplomatic response would, of course, remain uncertain. ;■;
